_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        This facility has been in an dormant state ( unoccupied) since August of 2002. There is Temporary  Emergency Response Plan in effect as this is written, the US Foodservice - Las Vegas Division Emergency Response Plan is the sole plan and that is to coordinate all emergency efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration and maintenance firm. This plan is designed to meet the following objectives:

1) To protect the Environment
2) To minimize property damage
In the case of an ammonia - related emergency, it is the policy of US Foodservice to allow the fire department and the refrigeration contractors to respond to the emergency.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled
This US Foodservice Facility is a freezing and storage warehouse for the perishable food industry. This facility operates an ammonia refrigeration system to provide cooling and freezing capabilities. The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in this system is in excess of 10,000 lbs. The ammonia inventory of this  system is approximately 16,000 lbs. Since ammonia releases from this system could pose a risk of offsite public impact and is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119), the system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of EPA's RMP program.

The closed loop ammonia refrigeration system at this US Foodservice Facility provides (2) major suction pressures (temperatures)
for use in the preservation of perishable food products.This provides refrigerant temperatures of -20F, with the use of low suction compressor

s and provides temperatures of +20F intermediate suction compressors.
The higher pressure portions of the system include the condenser, located on the roof, along with refrigerant vent lines where any leaks can dissipate to the air, joining ammonia produced by lightning where it can be consumed as it goes through a natural biodegradable process. Normal safeties include: high pressure cut-outs, relief valves, and ventilating systems for machine room areas.
The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system consists of a Frick Computer Controlled two temperature level, single stage system which operates at -20F. and +20F. Suction, and condensing with evaporative condensers at 95F.  The system provides cooling for the storage freezer,dock, two coolers, and the 75F. Dry storage area.
The system is controlled via microprocessors with hot gas defrost control, compressor sequencing, and evaporative condenser fan and pump control. The system is also capable of remote operation via modem and is capable of  temperature monitoring and control.
An ammonia detection system is installed as part of the central control system and will monitor locations where ammonia refrigerant is present. The system in theengine room will bring on emergency ventilation fans.

Summary of Worst case and Alternative Release Scenarios

The worst case release scenarion is determined to be a catastrophic release from the high pressure reciever V-1. This vessel operates at ambedient temperature and above atmospheric pressure.

The V-1 receiver is a vertical vessel and is 7 feet in diameter and 16 feet in length. When 69 % filled, vessel capacity is approximately 16,000 lbs of ammonia.

Assumed is that the release occurs through a circular hole located at the bottom of the vessel. For this worst case release scenario, the distance from the source to toxic endpoint is 1.4 miles or 7,392 feet.

The Worst Case Release Scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

The Worst Case Release Scenario weather conditions

which were used for this scenario are uncommon.

Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of these vessels:

Ammonia is not corrosive in this service:

Pressure safety valves limit operating pressures in these vessels and vessels have design margins of safety of about 4 to 1.

Alternative Release Scenario Analysis

An Alternative Release Scenario is chosen as a pipe failure. The potential for a pipe failure is significant given the extensive ammonia piping system extending through the Facility.

Assumed is the failure of a 1 inch pipe connected to the V-1 receiver. Using EPA-suggested meteoroligical parameters for alternative scenarios and following a one-hour release, the distance from release point to the toxic endpoint is 195 yards or 585 feet.

The Alternative Release Scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:

The high pressure liquid lines are located in enclosed areas that could help to contain such a release;

Industry Standards were followed for the manufacturing and quality control of these lines;

Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.

Vessel design uses a factor of approximately 4 to 1 margin for safety.

Active mitigation considered would be the Emergency Shut-Down System which permits system to equalize to 50-60 psig.

Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program (OSHA Process Safety Management CFR 1910-119) consists of the following elements :

Employee Participation
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training
Contractors
Pre-Start Up Safety Review
Mechanical Integrity
Hot Work Permit
Management of Change
Incident Investigation
Compliance Audits

Five Year Accident History
There have been no Ammonia Accidents at this Facility

Description of Emergency Plan

This facility has an Emergency Action Plan. The plan contains procedures describing how the facility would be responded to , if there was a ammonia spill and other emergencies, includi

ng critical operations shutdown procedures, means of reporting fires and emergencies, name of responsible person, alarm system, and fire prevention.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

A Process Hazard Analysis is scheduled for later in 2004, any recommendations resulting from this analysis will be evaluated and implemented as required.
